item.title: In Venezuela’s Election, Maduro’s Ruling Party Faces an Existential Vote
item.description: Sunday’s election could mark the end of a generation of rule by Venezuela’s socialist party. It could also usher in a period of profound uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Corina Machado, waving from the truck, and Edmundo González, at her side, during their final campaign rally this week in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Simone Biles Is Done Being Judged
item.description: Three years after she dropped out of the Tokyo Games with a mental block, she is back at the Olympics with a defiant attitude — and a sense of where she is in the air.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simone Biles performing on the balance beam in Tokyo in 2021.

item.title: Israel Hits Lebanon in Overnight Strikes After Soccer Field Attack
item.description: The overnight strikes, a response to a rocket attack from Lebanon that killed at least 12 civilians in an Israeli-controlled town, stopped short of a major escalation, for now.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Mourners surrounded the coffins of those killed in a rocket strike from Lebanon a day earlier, during a mass funeral in the town of Majdal Shams in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights on Sunday.

item.title: ‘All We Think of Is Him’: Putting Names and Faces to Bangladesh Carnage
item.description: The partial lifting of a communications blackout is providing a picture of the young victims of a brutal crackdown on protesters. Thousands of others have been swept into jails.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A daughter consoling her mother, who broke into tears after receiving the body of her son at a morgue in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday. Nearly 200 protesters have been killed in a crackdown by government forces, according to estimates.

item.title: Russia Punches Through Weakened Lines in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Military analysts say Russian forces are increasingly investigating Ukrainian lines to identify weakened positions before attacking and breaking through.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A soldier fired a howitzer toward Russian troops in the eastern Donetsk region this month. Ukrainian forces are strained by relentless Russian attacks along a more than 600-mile front.

item.title: ‘No One to Talk To’: The Lingering Trauma of Russian Rape in Ukraine
item.description: Prosecutors in Ukraine are pursuing cases of sexual assault by Russian soldiers, but survivors say more financial and psychological support is needed.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Ada Petriczko
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I had to somehow deal with it on my own,” said Daria, who said she was raped twice by Russian soldiers.

item.title: Here’s What Global Leaders Say About Kamala Harris
item.description: Heads of state and diplomats who have interacted with the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee say she uses humor, and talk of food, to help leaven hard discussions.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris arriving in Indianapolis after a flight aboard Air Force Two on Wednesday.

item.title: At Least 12 Killed in Rocket Attack From Lebanon in Golan Heights
item.description: It was the deadliest single attack from across Israel’s northern border in months of hostilities. Israel blamed Hezbollah, which denied responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene after a rocket fired from Lebanon struck a soccer field in Majdal Shams, a village in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, on Saturday.

item.title: Away From the War in Gaza, Another Palestinian Economy Is Wrecked
item.description: With the closure of checkpoints, Israeli Arabs cannot come to Jenin and Tulkarm to shop, and West Bank Palestinians cannot leave to work in Israel, cutting incomes and building militancy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Covering up the wall of a house that was damaged after an Israeli raid in the Jenin refugee camp in June.

item.title: New Israeli Evacuation Order in Gaza Displaces Palestinians Again
item.description: The order affected part of southern Gaza, while farther north, the Israeli military struck the grounds of a school it said was being used by Hamas, killing more than 30 people, Gaza officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Injured Palestinians being taken to a hospital in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: Blinken and a Top Chinese Official in Talks on U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state pressed China’s top foreign policy official on Beijing’s support for Russia’s efforts to rebuild its military industries during the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, in Vientiane, Laos, on Saturday.

item.title: More Trains, but Few Answers, After Railway Sabotage in France
item.description: France’s national railway company said traffic was gradually returning to normal a day after arsonists disrupted three high-speed rail lines. But who was behind the attacks remains mysterious.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: South Korea Reports Leak From a Top Intelligence Agency
item.description: It’s highly unusual for the nation’s authorities to publicly acknowledge a leak from the command​, which is one of South Korea’s top two spy agencies.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Looking at the North Korean side of the border from the unification observatory in Paju, South Korea, in June.

item.title: Chinese Swimmer Zhang Yufei Makes First Comments on Doping Case
item.description: Zhang Yufei, one of 23 athletes who tested positive for a banned substance before the last Olympics, said China did not allow doping, and offered a window into the stress the accusations have caused.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: China’s Zhang Yufei qualified for the semifinals of the 100-meter butterfly on Saturday morning.

item.title: Echoes of the Fort McMurray Disaster as Fire Sweeps Into Jasper, Alberta
item.description: About a third of the buildings in the mountain resort town have burned, raising questions about preparedness and the role of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The Fort McMurray wildfire melted almunium in cars and trucks that were caught in the blaze

item.title: How Katie Ledecky Won Bronze in the 400-meter Freestyle
item.description: Ledecky won her 11th Olympic medal, but was outpaced by Ariarne Titmus of Australia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Chang W. Lee and Gabriela Bhaskar
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Vault
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebeca Andrade became the first Brazilian to win an Olympic medal in women’s gymnastics when she earned gold in Tokyo in 2021.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Floor Exercise
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simone Biles of the United States on her way to winning a gold medal in floor exercise at the 2016 Olympics in Rio.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Uneven Bars
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: American gymnast Sunisa Lee won bronze in the uneven bars at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.

item.title: Your Guide to Olympic Gymnastics: Balance Beam
item.description: Want to follow the women’s gymnastics competition in Paris, but don’t understand the skills or how they’re scored? Here’s a guide.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Lauren Hernandez of the United States competing on the balance beam at the 2016 Olympics in Rio.

item.title: What to Know About Kamala Harris’s Foreign Policy Positions
item.description: Here is what we know about the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee’s views on issues like migration and the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris speaking during her first campaign rally, in Milwaukee, on Tuesday after she began her run to be the Democratic nominee for president.

item.title: Léon Marchand: The French Swimmer Who Is Carrying His Country on His Back
item.description: Léon Marchand, who has the potential to win medals in four individual events, bears much of the weight of France’s expectations. He is ready, he says, but adds, “it does feel weird.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:description: Léon Marchand practicing in the Olympics competition pool at the Paris La Défense Arena a few days before the start of the Games.

item.title: Snoop Dogg, NBC’s New Voice of the People
item.description: The network hired the rapper for an expanded role on its broadcasts of the Summer Games in Paris after posting record-low viewership of the Tokyo competition.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Eiffel Tower posing behind a noted American landmark.

item.title: Doused by Rain, Paris Opens Its Games With a Boat Party on the Seine
item.description: Undeterred by arson attacks on rail lines earlier in the day, the Parade of Nations continued beneath a glittering Eiffel Tower, where Celine Dion belted out a love anthem.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: The Eiffel Tower emitted beams of light during the climax of the opening ceremony.

item.title: Trump Says He and Netanyahu Remain on Good Terms
item.description: The former president met with the Israeli leader in Florida, a day after his main opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, and he both criticized Israel’s conduct of the war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump meets with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Celine Dion’s Performance Closes the Olympics Opening Ceremony
item.description: It was the first public performance since 2020 for Dion, who has a rare neurological disorder known as stiff person syndrome.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:description: Celine Dion performing from the Eiffel Tower to close the opening ceremony of the 2024 Paris Games.

item.title: When the Game Does Not End at the Final Whistle
item.description: Most soccer fans long ago internalized the idea that truth is a slippery concept.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: When there were fans in the stands, the score was 2-2. The match did not end that way.

item.title: Jasper Fire Worsened by Pyrocumulonimbus Cloud
item.description: Blazes that generate such stormy conditions can be nearly impossible to put out and pose special dangers to firefighters.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Jasper National Park
item.media:description: Smoke from a wildfire in Jasper National Park, Alberta, on Wednesday.

item.title: LeBron James and Coco Gauff are the U.S. Flag Bearers
item.description: The N.B.A. star LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers and the tennis star Coco Gauff were chosen by their peers to lead the United States at the opening ceremony in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Who Was the Heavy Metal Band at Opening Ceremony? That Was Gojira.
item.description: Gojira, a popular French band, became the first hard rock act to perform in an Olympic Games opening ceremony when it did a metal version of “Ah! Ça Ira,” a song that was popular during the French Revolution.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Gojira performs from windows and platforms at the Court of Cassation during the opening ceremony.

item.title: Rail Sabotage Blights an Olympic Moment for France
item.description: The arson attacks were carefully planned to cause maximum disruption on a train network so vast it is virtually impossible to fully secure.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers gathering in the main hall of Gare du Nord as they wait for their trains on the day of the opening ceremony of the Olympics Games, in Paris.

item.title: Anger Lingers Over Positive Doping Tests for Chinese Swimmers
item.description: In Paris, Chinese swimmers have been under extra scrutiny by doping watchdogs, but that hasn’t satisfied competitors like American star Caeleb Dressel.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Wang Shun of China during a training session at Paris La Défense Arena ahead of the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris.

item.title: Who Is Performing at the Olympics Opening Ceremony?
item.description: The ceremony will also provide a showcase for Aya Nakamura, a French-Malian singer, and a range of musical styles including disco, French hip-hop and zouk from the French Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:description: Lady Gaga performing in the opening ceremony in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Can Fees on Polluting Cars Clean the Air? London Has New Evidence.
item.description: The city’s expanded low-emissions zone, which was politically fraught, has cut emissions that contribute to health problems like asthma, new numbers show.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: A sign last year alerting drivers to the expansion of the city’s Ultra Low Emission Zone, or ULEZ, designed to cut pollution.

item.title: For Epidemics to Cross Oceans, Viruses on Ships Had to Beat the Odds
item.description: In the era when people traveled by sailing ship and steamer, illnesses usually burned themselves out before boats reached shore, a new study finds.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: Roland Dumas Dies at 101; French Foreign Minister Tainted by Scandal
item.description: A lawyer and confidant of François Mitterrand, he was in the forefront of French politics for decades, only to be undone by his taste for the high life.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Roland Dumas in 2014. He was the French foreign minister from 1984 to 1986 and from 1988 to 1993 and was later president of the Constitutional Council, France’s highest appeals body.

item.title: Suspected Arsonists Knew Exactly Where to Strike Paris Railways to Heighten Chaos
item.description: Thousands of miles of tracks leave the French system vulnerable to sabotage. But the suspected arsonists also knew just where to strike.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Workers reconnecting the signal box to its rail line in Val d’Yerres, France, on Friday.

item.title: Russia Raises Key Inflation Rate to 18 Percent
item.description: The move underscored the wartime risks for the Kremlin as the government pumps enormous sums of money into the Russian economy.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walking through a market in Shebekino, Russia, in May.

item.title: Town Famous for Royal and Hollywood Guests Is Ravaged by Wildfires
item.description: Fast-moving fires have destroyed a third of the buildings in the picturesque town of Jasper, Alberta, and its national park. But the mayor hopes to rebuild.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A residential neighborhood in Jasper, Alberta, destroyed this week by two large-scale wildfires.

item.title: U.K. Drops Opposition to I.C.C. Warrants for Netanyahu and Gallant
item.description: The new Labour government confirmed it would drop the previous government’s objection to I.C.C. arrest warrants for Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the defense minister, Yoav Gallant.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel attending a session in the Knesset, Israel’s parliament, in Jerusalem, this month.

item.title: Scandal Hits U.K.’s ‘Strictly Come Dancing,’ the Original ‘Dancing With the Stars’
item.description: The BBC said it would add chaperones to rehearsals after allegations of abusive behavior at a hugely popular dance show that inspired international versions.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Joe Giddens/PA Wire, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dancers at a “Strictly Come Dancing” live tour in Birmingham, England, in 2018. Allegations of abuse and bullying on the weekly television show have raised questions about the BBC’s handling of the show.

item.title: As Trump Looms, Blinken Aims to Reassure Allies on U.S. Commitment to Asia
item.description: Asian officials will press Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken about the former president and about Kamala Harris as he visits the region.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Washington in May.

item.title: With Kamala Harris, U.S. Free Trade Skepticism May Continue
item.description: The vice president has been critical of past trade deals. But her record suggests she could push for trade measures that address environmental issues.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Vice President Harris speaking about climate action in Charlotte, N.C., in April. Ms. Harris’s views on trade and economic issues are likely to become a focal point.

item.title: Arson Attack on France’s Rail Network: What We Know
item.description: Coordinated arson attacks on France’s high-speed rail network disrupted travel leading up to the Paris Olympics opening ceremony and into the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: SNCF (Societe Nationale des Chemins de fer Francais)
item.media:description: Railway workers and police officers at the site of one of the damaged train lines in northern France.

item.title: Arson Attacks on French Rail Leave Thousands Stranded
item.description: Hundreds were stuck at train stations in Paris and London as operators canceled and delayed trains on Friday after the attacks.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Hannah Beech and John Yoon
item.media:description: Travelers waiting outside the Gare Montparnasse train station in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Security Precautions Failed to Halt Train Sabotage in Paris
item.description: The attacks on several high-speed rail lines happened despite the sweeping mobilization of recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Security personnel redirecting people near the Trocadéro in Paris this week.

item.title: These Are the French Rail Lines Affected by the Arson Attacks
item.description: The arson has caused widespread travel disruptions in France ahead of the opening ceremony of the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Hundreds of travelers at the Gare Montparnasse, one of the major train stations in Paris, were affected by the disruptions.

item.title: Russia Warned Austin About Alleged Ukrainian Plot in Private Call
item.description: Russia’s defense minister said he needed to talk to Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin about an alleged Ukrainian operation. What happened next remains murky.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Since Russia invaded Ukraine, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has rarely spoken to his Russian counterpart.

item.title: Whose Politics Are More Turbulent, America’s or Australia’s?
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, citing the revolving door of prime ministers, said his own country was in no position to criticize the United States.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:description: President Joe Biden with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia at the White House last year.

item.title: Mexico Sinaloa Cartel Leader ‘El Mayo’ Is Arrested: What to Know
item.description: The U.S. said it had arrested Ismael Zambada García, a co-founder, and Joaquín Guzmán López, a son of another co-founder. Both are accused of involvement in fentanyl trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: Police and military patrolling Culiacán, the base of the Sinaloa cartel in Mexico, last year.

item.title: China Braces for Typhoon Gaemi After Devastation in Taiwan and the Philippines
item.description: The storm has already left a trail of destruction in Taiwan and the Philippines, where it killed at least 15 people.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Waves lashed the shore in China’s Fujian Province.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A new poll from the U.S. presidential race.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A new Times/Siena poll found Kamala Harris faring better with young and nonwhite voters than President Biden had.

item.title: As Starvation Spreads in Sudan, Military Blocks Aid Trucks at Border
item.description: A country torn apart by civil war could soon face one of the world’s worst famines in decades, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: The Olympics You Remember Are Back
item.description: Family, friends and fans were missing from two straight Covid Games. In Paris, one athlete said, competitors will have the kind of experience they dream about.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.category: United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stands are filled at rugby sevens on the first day of competition.

item.title: Vintage of War
item.description: A single image captures the change in fortunes for a wine cellar turned field hospital in Russian-occupied Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Nanna Heitmann and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: In Japan, Turning the Tables on Rude Customers
item.description: The country is famous for its hospitality. But businesses have had enough of people screaming at workers or tormenting them on social media.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuji Tanaka, managing director at Yumori Tanakaya, talking to a guest during check-in time in Nasushiobara, Japan, last month.

item.title: Breaking Down Netanyahu’s Speech in Congress
item.description: In his fourth speech to Congress, a record for a foreign leader, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel attempted to change the narrative about the fallout from the war in Gaza. Patrick Kingsley, the Jerusalem bureau chief for The New York Times, explains how Netanyahu used the speech to shift the focus to Iran and the threat it poses to Israel.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Farah Otero-Amad, Nikolay Nikolov, Rebecca Suner, Claire Hogan and James Surdam

item.title: 2 Top Leaders of Mexico’s Sinaloa Cartel, Including ‘El Mayo,’ in U.S. Custody
item.description: Ismael Zambada García and Joaquín Guzmán López helped run the Sinaloa Cartel, one of the most dominant criminal groups in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Ismael Zambada García, known as El Mayo, has been pursued by the U.S. government for years.

item.title: Israel Retrieves Bodies of 5 Hostages From Tunnel in Gaza
item.description: The military said that intelligence, including information from detained Palestinian militants, had led to the bodies in the Khan Younis area.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Anjana Sankar
item.media:description: The funeral in Tel Aviv on Thursday of Kiril Brodski, a soldier and one of the hostages whose body was recovered from Gaza.
